thread.title: All Three Major U.S. Stock Indices Are Now at Records -- Here's the Big Reason Why
thread.title_full: All Three Major U.S. Stock Indices Are Now at Records -- Here's the Big Reason Why - TheStreet

author: Valerie Young
title: All Three Major U.S. Stock Indices Are Now at Records -- Here's the Big Reason Why

organizations.name: u.s. stock indices are now at records

text:
The three major U.S. stock indexes closed at record highs Thursday as President Donald Trump promised tax reform soon. Oil prices rallied and energy and financial shares rose.
The Dow gained 0.58%, closing at a record 20,171 . Its previous high was 20,100, set on Jan. 26.
The S&P 500 was up 0.57%, posting a new record close of 2,307. The Nasdaq increased 0.58% to 5,715, a record closing high for the third consecutive day.
"The backdrop of better economic data and better earnings are kind of buoying the market and supporting the levels that we have right now," said Jim Davis, regional investment manager of U.S. Bank's private client group. "Companies and investors are waiting to get more clarity on the issues that are near and dear to their heart: taxes, regulation, and infrastructure spending."
In fact, during a meeting with U.S. aviation executives earlier Thursday, Donald Trump said he plans to reveal a tax reform plan in the coming weeks.
"Lowering the overall tax burden on American business is big league. That's coming along very well," Trump said at the meeting. "We're way ahead of schedule, I believe. And we're going to announce something I would say over the next two or three weeks that will be phenomenal in terms of tax."
The financial sector led the markets as Goldman Sachs ( GS ) gained 1.6% and JPMorgan Chase ( JPM ) jumped 1.5%. The Financial Select Sector SPDR ETF ( XLF ) rose 1.5%.
The energy sector also was a leading gainer Thursday as West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled up 1.3% to $53 a barrel. The Energy Select Sector SPDR ETF ( XLE ) gained 1.2%.
"There's been a nice rebound in oil and that's probably propelling the energy sector today," said Davis. "This is definitely a kind of a wait-and-see attitude in the markets."
Shares of Twitter ( TWTR ) fell 12% as fourth-quarter revenue at the company came in below forecasts. The social media company reported fourth-quarter revenue of $717 million. Fourth-quarter adjusted earnings were 16 cents a share, beating estimates of 12 cents.
Twitter also posted flat sequential user growth in the fourth quarter. "While revenue growth continues to lag audience growth, we are applying the same focused approach that drove audience growth to our revenue product portfolio, focusing on our strengths and the real-time nature of our service," Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey said in a statement. "This will take time, but we're moving fast to show results." TheStreet's Jim Cramer says there's no reason to buy shares of Twitter: Coca-Cola ( KO ) was the biggest loser on the Dow Jones Industrial Average , tumbling even though the beverage giant posted earnings and sales that topped estimates. Coca-Cola reported adjusted earnings of 37 cents a share, matching estimates, while revenue of $9.41 billion beat expectations. Net revenue for the quarter declined 6%, due to the "impact from foreign currency and structural changes," the company said. Coke declined 1.7%. Coke's Chairman and CEO Muhtar Kent said he is "worried" about a potential border tax . Here's why Jim Cramer prefers Pepsi over Coke: Cigna ( CI ) shares fell 0.2% after a federal judge blocked its $54 billion proposed merger with Anthem ( ANTM ) . U.S. District Court Judge Amy Berman sided with the Department of Justice, ruling that the deal was anticompetitive for other health care insurers. Tesla ( TSLA ) shares were up 2.6% after the company said it would stop production at its California assembly plant for a week in February to test-build the Model 3 sedan later this month, Reuters reported . News also surfaced Tesla workers want to form a union . Whole Foods Market ( WFM ) gained 3.5% on Thursday after the grocer said that it plans to close nine stores and reduce expansion. The store also reported earnings of 30 cents a share, missing estimates of 39 cents, while revenue climbed 1.8% to $4.92 billion, but came in lower than expected. Comparable-store sales fell 2.4% and the company lowered it 2017 guidance. Given the latest report, the grocery chain may be prime activist target . Dunkin' Brands ( DNKN ) reported earnings of 61 cents a share, a reversal from a year-earlier loss of 10 cents a share. Revenue climbed 5.8% during fourth quarter. Shares of Dunkin' Brands were up 4%. TheStreet 's Brian Sozzi talked at length with Dunkin' Chairman and CEO Nigel Travis here . Viacom ( VIAB ) reported earnings of $1.04 a share for its fiscal first quarter, beating estimates. It earned $1.18 a share a year earlier. Revenue of $3.32 billion was up 5.4% from the $3.15 billion reported last year. Shares of Viacom were up 4.6%. CVS Health ( CVS ) shares were up slightly after the company said net revenue increased 11.7% to $45.97 billion, but fell below consensus estimates. Adjusted earnings of $1.71 a share were better than expected. Yum! Brands ( YUM ) shares increased 1.2% after the company reported earnings of 76 cents a share, beating estimates, but sales of $2.02 billion came in below expectations. Here's a look at where the owner of Taco Bell, KFC and Pizza Hut will be opening more outlets in 2017 . Weekly jobless claims in the U.S. fell 12,000 to 234,000. Economists expected claims of 250,000. St. Louis Fed President James Bullard said at in a speech Thursday interest rates would likely remain low in the "near term." Bullard said that Donald Trump's policies of deregulation, infrastructure spending and tax reform could lead to increases in productivity in 2018 and 2019. Chicago Fed President Charles Evans, who also gave a speech Thursday, said that the Fed must hit its inflation target of 2% to maintain its "credibility." "Given how long we have been below our inflation objective, I believe the risks are greater that the public doubts our resolve to bring inflation up to 2 percent than they question our will to bring it back down if we were to overshoot 2 percent by a meaningful amount," he said. "Preserving the Fed's credibility currently requires providing sufficient accommodation to achieve our symmetric inflation objective and maximum employment."
